subject: Remove default_bind_mount_logs from config changes.
messages:
[{'account_id': 13095, 'date': '2018-01-26 18:56:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2018-01-29 13:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:46:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Will test an upgrade with it. Not merging without testing it manually, because it might as well break the upgrades.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:50:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Will test an upgrade with it. Not merging without testing it
 > manually, because it might as well break the upgrades.

Wrong wording. I'd prefer waiting for tomorrow's periodics to know the state with the current pending patch [1] before merging this one.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/538315/"}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-01-29 21:17:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-26 18:56:07.000000000', 'message': "Remove default_bind_mount_logs from config changes.

Changing the value for default_bind_mount_logs on upgrade will make all
container restart. It only make sense to add this to the config when:
- you upgrade to the release that changes the default behavior
    - this is to keep the old default.
- The setting is not set in the configuration.
    - If the config is present, you don't want to change it.

Change-Id: I37217352357dee8c844d3b20d28075f7e4ef1223
Related-Bug: #1745212
(cherry picked from commit 7cd9fec86f11a294b67b8ae990141cdb7a97fdfe)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove default_bind_mount_logs from config changes.

Changing the value for default_bind_mount_logs on upgrade will make all
container restart. It only make sense to add this to the config when:
- you upgrade to the release that changes the default behavior
    - this is to keep the old default.
- The setting is not set in the configuration.
    - If the config is present, you don't want to change it.

Change-Id: I37217352357dee8c844d3b20d28075f7e4ef1223
Related-Bug: #1745212
(cherry picked from commit 7cd9fec86f11a294b67b8ae990141cdb7a97fdfe)

[{'created': '2018-01-29 17:13:08.000000000', 'message': "Remove Simple Crypto plugin production warning

Folks are using this for production, and in reality, even though the
plugin is not ideal, one can take measures to secure this backend enough
that it will be fine for most use-cases. Taking this into account, I'm

commit_message:
Remove Simple Crypto plugin production warning

Folks are using this for production, and in reality, even though the
plugin is not ideal, one can take measures to secure this backend enough
that it will be fine for most use-cases. Taking this into account, I'm
removing this warning that's putting users/deployers off.

Change-Id: I35ba3f78da6c77e2812fc7ec259cf149ab825caa

subject: Only run openstack-tox-functional on nova stable branches
messages: [{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-01-29 20:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 20:34:47.000000000', 'message': "Only run openstack-tox-functional on nova stable branches

Change Ia684786d1622da7af31aa4479fc883a7c65848ff creates a
nova-specific tox functional job in the nova repo. That
is merged on master but not stable branches yet.

This change makes the openstack-tox-functional job only run
on stable branches since on master we run nova-tox-functional.

Since the functional py35 job was only running on master, it's
simply removed since nova-tox-functional-py35 (defined in-repo)
replaces it.

A follow up change will remove openstack-tox-functional altogether.

Change-Id: Ibdd11c4d461b8434bf90df70864c4fcdbbc2304e
"}]
commit_message:
Only run openstack-tox-functional on nova stable branches

Change Ia684786d1622da7af31aa4479fc883a7c65848ff creates a
nova-specific tox functional job in the nova repo. That
is merged on master but not stable branches yet.

This change makes the openstack-tox-functional job only run
on stable branches since on master we run nova-tox-functional.

Since the functional py35 job was only running on master, it's
simply removed since nova-tox-functional-py35 (defined in-repo)
replaces it.

A follow up change will remove openstack-tox-functional altogether.

Change-Id: Ibdd11c4d461b8434bf90df70864c4fcdbbc2304e

[{'created': '2018-01-03 16:35:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add a return code check to the osa wrapper

Due to our use of block/rescue pattern in some of the playbooks/roles
the after run report will show something "failed" even when the run
succeeds. This creates a poor user experience when looking at the
playbook runs, especially as a new user. This change adds a simple
return code check when the openstack-ansible wrapper is used and reports
if the run succeeds or is a failure based on the RC. This should help
users understand when something actually fails, at a glance.

> NOTE: This change should no longer be needed as soon as we're able
  to move to ansible 2.5 which improves the UX when the block/rescue
  pattern is used.

Change-Id: Ic54a7524c09a170e20830c5f8d2c2a0658159ed0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add a return code check to the osa wrapper

Due to our use of block/rescue pattern in some of the playbooks/roles
the after run report will show something "failed" even when the run
succeeds. This creates a poor user experience when looking at the
playbook runs, especially as a new user. This change adds a simple
return code check when the openstack-ansible wrapper is used and reports
if the run succeeds or is a failure based on the RC. This should help
users understand when something actually fails, at a glance.

> NOTE: This change should no longer be needed as soon as we're able
  to move to ansible 2.5 which improves the UX when the block/rescue
  pattern is used.

With this change a user will see an "EXIT NOTICE" which is reported in a
way that resembles how ansible reports information on a playbook run
which should be simple to see and understand in almost all cases.

Change-Id: Ic54a7524c09a170e20830c5f8d2c2a0658159ed0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Closes-Bug: #1743382
'}]
commit_message:
tasks: lxc_post_install: Handle missing init.scope scope

The init.scope was added in systemd-v226 and support for the pid
controller was added in systemd-v227. However, stable distributions may
be on older systemd version so we need to check whether the scope exists
before we try to adjust the maximum number of processes for that scope.

Change-Id: Ic38e17d110e7a72770286c2faf571ba03bde7f32
Link: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/efdb02375beb0a940c3320865572913780b4d7de
Link: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/03a7b521e3ffb7f5d153d90480ba5d4bc29d1e8f
Closes-Bug: #1743382

commit_message:
Use relative path in ipv6 nic configs

The path to run-os-net-config.sh in these nic config templates for ci
should be relative, not absolute. The absolute path does not honor a
different directory specified via --templates, and it also fails the
overcloud deploy entirely b/c the absolute path does not exist in the
plan in swift.

Change-Id: I85ac081571965f42beef4bd283db985b9a03078f
(cherry picked from commit c74318381c91751e0f43f1b99f26011cecafe440)

commit_message:
Create compute pre_upgrade script for oooq.

In TripleO CI the hostname doesn't
have an indicator of the role the node
takes. For that reason, it's necessary
to modify the condition that identifies
the overcloud node as a compute one.

Change-Id: Ie544882cb262ba8aa578cf648fc2a9a8fedc47fc

commit_message:
Set restrictive file permissions on Ceph keyrings for non-containerized deployment

Pass mode parameter 0640 and user and group ownership to puppet-ceph for
Ceph openstack client keyrings during non-containerized deployment.

Author:    Keith Schincke <kschinck@redhat.com>
Co-Author:    John Fulton <fulton@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie968e6abc6969c37be0a62ac45999093120673d4
Depends-On: Ie968e6abc6969c37be0a62ac45999093120673d4
Partial-Bug: #1720787
(cherry picked from commit bdf1ade1b9de994c3098fb17cca6dd64b3d14cd5)

commit_message:
Remove scenario.img_file from queens release onwards

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/535831/ will auto sets the same
  from queens onwards using tempest config tool. So removing it from
  queens releases.

Depends-On: I44936418ce359eaf04c4f47f0961687d65d45c6c

Change-Id: I6cd7eb36bb81df4f1c88c5154a40dafe859d6d6b

commit_message:
Replace curly quotes with straight quotes

Curly quotes usually input from Chinese input method.
When read from english context, it makes some confusion.

Change-Id: Iac767651ec7afd1ef8a656c96a5735ed00310319

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 15:38:32.000000000', 'message': "Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create ipv6 multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd.

Change-Id: Iba56667e11510a1cc2470a7dfdc6bc0158878010
(cherry picked from commit 3fc4da76ab0970b6cc2a2648d1908158fa0fcc02)
(cherry picked from commit 7232568a267622a15eeef663978e0650a8ea1f85)

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline

Change-Id: Iba56667e11510a1cc2470a7dfdc6bc0158878010

"}]
commit_message:
Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create ipv6 multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd.

Change-Id: Iba56667e11510a1cc2470a7dfdc6bc0158878010

commit_message:
Start using nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

We may want to also consider a massive cleanup of the existing
network dir with a proper deprecation period, but that is an
exercise left for later.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd (though there are some settings like MTU that
are not actually good for a real deployment).

Change-Id: I9fd8b8bbcf18d26b1e05d33e2598c0d146814aff
(cherry picked from commit 10b749c043700369d4ea89d5a238173c4dde1d7e)
(cherry picked from commit f09e6acefd93b800e275131a3712f905bf4e3aa5)

commit_message:
Remove use of unsupported TEMPEST_SERVICES variable

TEMPEST_SERVICES global variable is not supported
by devstack since long back.
- I380dd20e5ed716a0bdf92aa02c3730359b8136e4
- I9c24705e494689f09a885eb0a640efd50db33fcf

Service availability of tempest known services will be
set by devstack with local check.
- I02be777bf93143d946ccbb8e9eff637bfd1928d4

This commit removes the unused TEMPEST_SERVICES setting
Related-Bug: #1743688

Change-Id: I753390dd237dd5091025d7fea8f6153fc5362a0f

commit_message:
Set glance images dir owners each time

After a deployment of Queens, glance's images directory comes up with
ownership of `root:root` when it should be `glance:glance`. This
prevents an end user from uploading an image.

This patch removes the stat check of the images directory and always
ensures the directory is created. If the directory already exists,
the create task will ensure that the directory has its ownership
set appropriately.

Closes-Bug: 1742951
Change-Id: I286d6fbdfdec932ea031916f5460710a23d68374

I'm not sure I like the processing fork and all. The architecture seems a bit fragile to me in general."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-01-26 16:31:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-01-27 01:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Thanks for your review.

Julien,
For timeout, We need a fork process to trigger the evaluator process as it's not periodically called.
Current fork process is very light weight: just sleep then send one notification.
Do you have any fragile cases? Maybe evaluator crashed after sending "alarm.timeout.end", which is confusing to restarted evaluator? We can put more data in notification payload and add more check to make it robust.

Gordon,
I'm not clear about "send new alarms to it's own queue." Could you pls. elaborate?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-01-28 10:05:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, clearly if your process crash, it does not work. There's nothing resilient here, and that scares me a lot. :("}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-01-28 10:07:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, clearly if your process crash, it does not work. There's nothing resilient here, and that scares me a lot. :("}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-01-29 07:18:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Julien,

Let's put timestamp for each notification, like alarm.timeout.[start|end], so evaluator can know exactly what happened on which specific point. E.g. 'alarm.timeout.end' event in the queue when evaluator start, it can figure out that timeout should have been expired 5s ago, thus do it now.

Probably need recording timeout handling status in DB, in case of crash/restart issue.

I'll make a new version."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-01-29 09:39:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think that we should use the database if we want to be resilient. Then all you have to do is to store and update the last timestamp of the received notification that matches a timeout-alarm, and evaluate (SELECT) those who expired…'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-04-21 02:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-08-23 02:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-08-23 02:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(8 comments)

ok, i looked at logic and it's sort of ambiguous.

i think we need docs to explain what is happening here. i see the spec[1] mention something about timeout state being added but this doesn't seem to implement it? i'd prefer if we detail how this works because this will be very difficult to maintain i think if only you understand it :)

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/239312/8/specs/mitaka/event-alarm-timeout.rst"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-09-07 12:31:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-09-08 07:13:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(9 comments)

Gordon/Julien,
Thanks for your time. You are worrying 3 things:
1. Why send event for timeout handling?
Event evaluator is driven by event, so we have no chance to handle timeout, if no event comes in specific time frame. Another good thing is synchronization, pls. see the following.

2. Why not use separate queue for alarm.timeout.* ?
Separate queue would leads some duplicated code. Furthermore, we need handle the synchronization between related events @ different queues.
e.g. required_event on one queue, and 'alarm.timeout.end' on another, so that we need add tricky lock to avoid race condition.

3. TIMEOUT state in spec is not necessary, and can be mapped to current OK state. So still 3 states:

insufficient data: unknown state
OK: Unalarm state when either enough data indicate so or timeout happen
ALARM: alarm state when data meet requirement or specified event come."}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-09-19 07:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-09-19 07:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11235, 'date': '2016-09-19 07:53:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Gordon/Julien,
New PS addressed part of your comments. Following answers could address rest of them:
1. Why send event for timeout handling?
Event evaluator is driven by event, so we have no chance to handle timeout, if no event comes in specific time frame. Another good thing is synchronization, pls. see the following.
2. Why not use separate queue for alarm.timeout.* ?
Separate queue would leads some duplicated code. Furthermore, we need handle the synchronization between related events @ different queues.
e.g. required_event on one queue, and 'alarm.timeout.end' on another, so that we need add tricky lock to avoid race condition.
3. TIMEOUT state in spec is not necessary, and can be mapped to current OK state. So still 3 states:
insufficient data: unknown state
OK: Unalarm state when either enough data indicate so or timeout happen
ALARM: alarm state when data meet requirement or specified event come."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-09-19 08:05:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

So until the general design of this is changed, I don't think we want to merge this.

The whole process spawning is way too fragile. As I already stated somewhere, this should probably leverage a database entry for the alarm with the latest trigger time and a worker checking that regularly. This would be way more reliable than the current design."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-19 08:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

commit_message:
Enable event-alarm timeout

New timeout parameter enabling event-alarm become 'ok' if no desired
event come after specified timeout

Change-Id: I0b8a678360d69ece119865960335d0ac3096e91c
Implements: blueprint event-alarm-timeout

commit_message:
Don't manually invoke pip. Use the devstack function instead.

This will help install aodh in a proxy environment.

Depends-On: Ia35ab8de4ed6487faf703cc36da3a183ac48a60d
Change-Id: I9c800816c014ab9f5fa474ffee05f43ddda471cf

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ie9a68e1b4ae73ecc20f057717d2cd5ca97e726c0

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I07dac0ba00ff76ea39894795324aceaaea434f29

commit_message:
placement: using the dict format for the allocation in claim_resources

In the placement API version 1.12, the dict format is consistent format in
the APIs `PUT /allocations/{consumer_uuid}`, `GET /allocations/{consumer_uuid}`
and `GET /allocation_candidates`. This patch switches to this consistent
format in the claim_resources method.

There is one upgrade scene which needs to be care. Since we send alternative
hosts to the compute node as Selection object. The Selection object includes
the json dict of allocation object. That means if a try of instance building
happened in the middle of upgrade, the old format allocation json dict will
send back to the new version cell conductor. So the claim_resources method
still needs to support old version allocation json format.

Change-Id: I4314ade528c9cb69bbf6c55d31566e1e188fef09

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I373258e1b2147a53f1275a4679d7a55cb4b28fc3

commit_message:
Extend the validation for generic pollster

In this blueprint, the following tasks have been done.

a. The mechanism to implement the meter definition validator
b. The design SNMP validator

Most of the work have done in the change set:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262660/

During the review, llu and I have agreement on implementing a
mechanism for the new validator can be added in the future and the
validator can be loaded dynamicly during loading the defferent
meter definition.

Based on the above reason, I write down this design in order to
add the new validator in the future.

Change-Id: Idd2fa196ca71bcb42609b113b730c7a5a28726a0
blueprint: extend-validation-for-generic-pollster

This BP supports alarm type for event-alarm

adding new alarm type(like comb and event-timeout) in future is easy.

blueprint alarm-type-for-event-alarm

Hi Gord,

Can you please give me some pointers on how to start and what should I do and consider.

The thing is that from what I see, is that there are only evaluator alarms at the moment, so I don't know how to start working on an alarm that is not supposed to be evaluated.

Thanks,
Alexey"}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-12-15 13:39:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

if i recall, i think we were going to leverage the Alarm CRUD notifications? when you create an alarm, it creates notification, when you update alarm, it creates notification, etc... i think you wanted to listen to update notification?'}, {'account_id': 19122, 'date': '2016-12-15 13:44:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Gord,
What you are talking is some other blueprint that Dong is working on that is related to vitrage-aodh integration, but it is not what this blueprint is about.
Please take a look at my blueprint, and see the change that I am talking about.
Thanks in advance :)'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2016-12-15 14:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-12-15 14:53:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

... i did read your patch. guess you don't like my solution.

alternatively, just 'evaluate' on set_state REST calls?"}, {'account_id': 19122, 'date': '2016-12-15 15:03:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Gord,

This blueprint doesn't talk about the notification because it is handled by Dong.
What I am talking about is to create a new alarm in aodh, because event alarm is not good enough for us.
So I want to create a new type of alarm in aodh called generic alarm or external alarm which will raise a new alarm in aodh without evaluating it.
How should I create such an alarm in aodh? I understood from Julien that it needs to be in the storage folder. Can you maybe elaborate more about that? what should be done there? and maybe in some other places in aodh in order for me to successfully create such an alarm.

Thanks,
Alexey"}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-12-15 15:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

i would start looking at api since that seems like all you want to use. just walk through workflow of creating an alarm (which has the fields you want) and how you envision triggering it.

add an alarm_rule if needed, https://github.com/openstack/aodh/tree/master/aodh/api/controllers/v2/alarm_rules'}, {'account_id': 19122, 'date': '2016-12-15 15:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Where can I find such a workflow of adding an new type of alarm (such as the event alarm) to aodh?'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-12-15 15:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Collect neutron security group meters for instance ports

Ceilometer Currently has no support for metering the drop bytes/pkts
for instance ports associated with security group. By default the
security group is enabled for every instance port. The security group
meters are important for security analysis.

This spec is to collect send/receive/drop meters, the meters can be
used for security analysis or alarming.

Co-Authored-By: jizilian(jizilian@cn.ibm.com)
Co-Authored-By: lulk(lulk@cn.ibm.com)
blueprint: support-to-collect-neutron-port-meters
Change-Id: I765eb4eb1849519efa3db3534a35cfbd13993e0b

commit_message:
devstack: update local.conf.example to use lib/neutron

now networking-odl/devstack is using lib/neutron instead of
lib/neutron-legacy. So update local.conf.example to adapt it.

Change-Id: Ia28df4e0fae735d9ab365e5c64c75fb88af6fe90
Closes-Bug: #1740007

commit_message:
Helm-Test: remove user and tenant creation from test context

This PS removes the user managemnt from the rally driven helm tests
which allows LDAP and other read only sources being used to validate
service functionality, in addition to reducing false -ve results in
the Zuul gates.

Change-Id: I1cc0e99bf74d578648b3cd40eaf60c1804044d88

commit_message:
LOG.warning on unplug_vifs InstanceNotFound

This changes the LOG level from exception to warning on an
InstanceNotFound exception during unplug_vifs. Since no action is being
taken on this exception the warning level is more appropriate.

Change-Id: I8778e3aa80089445fb51431db9a2feeb9db0399b

commit_message:
use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use “.” to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more:
http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/writing-style/code-conventions

Change-Id: Icaf20628e7b7480ee4ca4c85f9c5a3802b817070

A sample pipe yaml could be like this:
    - name: bracketer_source
      events:
          - "compute.instance.create.start"
          - "compute.instance.create.end"
      sinks:
          - bracketer_sink

    - name: bracketer_sink
      transformers:
          - name: "bracketer"
            parameters:
                source:
                   - event_type: "compute.instance.create.start"
                   - event_type: "compute.instance.create.end"

                target:
                     event_type: "compute.instance.create.latency"
                     traits:
                           name: "instance_create_latency"
                           type: "int"
      publishers:
          - direct://'}, {'account_id': 11189, 'date': '2015-07-02 07:45:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

an example of a new 'transformed' event could be like:

<Event: 69fcaba9-5a0b-4fa7-80e4-1c61396ceb0c, compute.instance.create.latency, 2015-07-01 00:34:28.306154, <Trait: state 1 building> <Trait: root_gb 2 1> <Trait: user_id 1 8e92392764a143fe85091e96566b7c9a> <Trait: service 1 compute> <Trait: disk_gb 2 1> <Trait: instance_type 1 m1.tiny> <Trait: tenant_id 1 64c0e386d07545c295decdd4a93987dc> <Trait: ephemeral_gb 2 0> <Trait: instance_type_id 2 2> <Trait: vcpus 2 1> <Trait: memory_mb 2 512> <Trait: instance_id 1 06ad6783-59c2-42af-a529-9785acd45910> <Trait: host 1 yuntong-ThinkStation> <Trait: compute_instance_create_latency 1 8.371539>>"}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-07-02 12:56:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Sorry for delayed answer I had vacation.

Thanks yuntongjin my example is the similar:

    - name: bracketer_source
      events:
          - "compute.instance.create.end"
          - "compute.instance.delete.end"
      sinks:
          - bracketer_sink

    - name: bracketer_sink
      transformers:
          - name: "bracketer"
            parameters:
                source:
                   - event_type: "compute.instance.create.end"
                   - event_type: "compute.instance.delete.end"

                target:
                     event_type: "compute.instance.lifespan"
                     traits:
                           name: "instance_lifespan"
                           type: "int"
                           value: compute.instance.create.end.generated - compute.instance.delete.end.generated
      publishers:
          - direct://

So we will have new events that with servers life span time as trait.'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-07-02 13:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-07-02 13:04:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

in example trait type int because we do not have timedelta type for trait, so will have time in seconds for life span here'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-07-02 13:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-07-02 14:18:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

so it looks like you're calculating a sample (measurement). if we capture that as event, is that a completely new event with a single trait?  or is it a part of the end bracketing event?

i personally see a sample created (which i think is a good idea.) i'm not sure the value of having it as an event though."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-02 14:30:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified+1

in my example I'm interested in new events that creates for dropped servers that was successfully created and deleted from the cloud. That means that I'm interested actually in one trait 'instance_lifespan' other traits like 'instance_id' 'host' should be taken from the parent ones and we do not need to set them in yaml.

So new event appears only it sequence of events(here two) were got and new traits could be based on received events or set manually if needed."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-07-02 18:07:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

cool cool. so my main question is why is this an event and not a sample? is this not something that you'd want to derive statistics from?"}, {'account_id': 11189, 'date': '2015-07-03 01:02:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

In some case like we want to triage an alarm from the bracketer result,then it should be send as new event. 

But most of case, it should be consume as an sample. 
in which the bracketer event can be send back to notification_topics and consume by sample plugin.

A flag should be set in yaml to indicate this.'}, {'account_id': 11189, 'date': '2015-07-03 08:18:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

when calculate instance latency from notification compute.instance.create.begin/end, the instance create may failed and send out compute.instance.create.error.'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-07-06 20:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Its close to end of August -- need this BP approved and implemented! It is important for Telco use cases where they would like to measure provisioning latency etc.
1) I know Lianhao and others called out to keeping timeout separate .. I would like to understand how that timeout will be used to clean-up dangling event bracketers. For instance a VM start launch instance that never captured a matching end launch. Should the "right" bracket specify may be multiple matchers such as successful launch and failed-launch and just pure timeout?
2) I like the paramter "emit" alarm event. If it is false, could this feature be used purely for side-effect, such as in metering where some statistics are updated. For example, if we were curious how long it takes to launch containers, and the number of containers may be two orders of magnitude more than virtual machines, might want to just maintain statistics such as average launch time, average lifespan etc.
3) Last but not least, could be keep this event pipeline enhancement dynamically active/inactive. That is something we can turn off and on at will, so we can randomly sample system health and fulfillment times. This enables more use cases.'}, {'account_id': 11189, 'date': '2015-08-24 04:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

malini-k-bhandaru		6:18 AM
Patch Set 13:
Its close to end of August -- need this BP approved and implemented! It is important for Telco use cases where they would like to measure provisioning latency etc. 1) I know Lianhao and others called out to keeping timeout separate .. I would like to understand how that timeout will be used to clean-up dangling event bracketers. For instance a VM start launch instance that never captured a matching end launch. Should the "right" bracket specify may be multiple matchers such as successful launch and failed-launch and just pure timeout? 
-- request ID is included in bracket event, and it should be used to match bracket event, so that at least leftover event won't break begin-end event matching.
In the worst case, there will be lots of unmatched leftover event,i'm not sure this need to be considered, if yes, then an possible way is to limit the pipeline cache.    
2) I like the paramter "emit" alarm event. If it is false, could this feature be used purely for side-effect, such as in metering where some statistics are updated. For example, if we were curious how long it takes to launch containers, and the number of containers may be two orders of magnitude more than virtual machines, might want to just maintain statistics such as average launch time, average lifespan etc. 
-- This sounds like event aggragate, like we already have in sample transform, accumulator/arithmetic. we could have similar aggragate in event transform, shall we have seperate spec to address this?
 
3) Last but not least, could be keep this event pipeline enhancement dynamically active/inactive. That is something we can turn off and on at will, so we can randomly sample system health and fulfillment times. This enables more use cases.
-- I think this could be very useful for operators, is it possible to achieve this by having similar way in alarm evaluator, which is storing transformer in DB and expose API to manipulate them?'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2015-08-27 15:41:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

guys review please the spec, do we still have any particulars to discuss and improve or can finally approve it and move following disscusion to patch with implementation? (3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2016-02-04 14:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-02-04 15:53:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-ceilometer-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/67/162167/17/check/gate-ceilometer-specs-docs/8619884//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 48s
- gate-ceilometer-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/67/162167/17/check/gate-ceilometer-specs-python27/852dfa1/ : SUCCESS in 2m 14s'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2016-02-04 16:49:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2016-02-04 16:50:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-02-04 18:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-ceilometer-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/67/162167/18/check/gate-ceilometer-specs-docs/40b5d37//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 06s
- gate-ceilometer-specs-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/67/162167/18/check/gate-ceilometer-specs-python27/5098eea/ : SUCCESS in 2m 09s'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2016-02-05 02:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review-1

First and foremost, would like to state this BP is of value, and should be approved and implemented for Mitaka. Capturing latency of CRUD events is essential for Telco adoption, something higher level management applications will seek insight into. Thus I echo Nadya Shakhat comments.

That said I have a concern about how timeouts of bracket events are handled. At the very least the backing cache (memcache or other used by the multiple agents) needs to be periodically inspected and either a timeout event emitted for each such dangling bracket and any other metrics/statistics updated.  Example  {<tenant-a. vm-launch-event> ... wait wait wait}. The <tenant-a.vm-launch-successful-event> not having arrived.
Even a simple pattern such as  E1.(E2 or E3) to capture something along the lines of start.(end or fail) will be valuable. Not necessary in this first incarnation/implementation to have to support complex event match patterns to be extremely useful.

Additionally I would like a word or two on how one might update a statistics event or database element, as opposed to creating a new event. Thus being able to attach a snippet of code/callback to such a bracket definition. May be even a disable new-event emit flag.

Last but not least, this feature has a documentation component, where how it can be used is important, so different cloud operators can define their own bracket events. In addition, I think we should provide a few bracket event definitions that might be commonly desired and in the description file have an enable disable flag (list # in a bash script file).'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2016-02-05 05:47:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

@malini-k-bhandaru, event-timeout is covered in aodh spec  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/aodh/+spec/event-alarm-timeout.

I don't know why we need to update existing event instead of creating new one, I think this is not what event meant to be, each event has a timestamp and I think in most cases we don't want to change that. 

Agreed that we need to provide some bracket transformer examples for common usage case, may be in a sample pipeline configure file?"}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2016-02-05 05:49:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10987, 'date': '2016-02-05 13:29:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)

Lianhai Lu and malini-k-bhandaru thank you for review.

@malini-k-bhandaru:
During our discussion under the spec we came to decision that event timeout alerting should be implemented on AODH side because alarms is operated by end user unlike pipeline.yaml file. Without emission of timeout-event we do not need to make periodic looking through the cache even for multi-agent configuration. 

What we probably want to have is an opportunity to remove old data by demand, by default the oldest data will be deleted by cache to release free space for writing new data when it is needed.

I agree with Lianhao that we do not need to update existing events it seems that using timestamp field is fair enough to get the most recent events from database

Documentation is obviously important and I've already mentioned that in spec's Documentation Impact. Should I increase description for that section?

@Lianhao Lu:
Answer is inline, thank you for the question."}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2016-02-06 02:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-02-08 11:48:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Code-Review+1

(4 comments)

Some comments within to clarify some grammatical errors (there are others, I just picked the ones where they seemed to be confusing the meaning of the section) but in general I think this is a useful idea.

I worry a bit that the implementation will be considerably more complex than things sound in this spec, but that's the nature of this kind of thing, so as long as we know going into it...

I agree that more detail on the caching (especially timeout) is desirable so I'm just +1 for now."}, {'account_id': 7478, 'date': '2016-02-08 13:42:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 7478, 'date': '2016-02-08 13:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7478, 'date': '2016-02-08 13:45:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

I've uploaded a new variant with several noted about cache usage. Please pay attention to it"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-02-08 13:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Verified+1

commit_message:
Add read performance testing to monasca-api

Using Jmeter to query monasca-api and collect performance numbers related
to database performance and monasca-api interaction.

[{'account_id': 27657, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:27:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:27:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27657, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:30:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27657, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:32:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27657, 'date': '2018-01-17 03:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27657, 'date': '2018-01-17 21:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-01-18 10:19:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Horizon UI message when browser cookies disabled

Used dijango's CSRF_FAILURE_VIEW setting to create
a view indicating the reason the request was rejected.
This information is passed on to the login page so it
can render the error.

Change-Id: I61c7195c9bafb269816fde12b058e19ebc69953c
Closes-Bug: #1412483

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 17.0.0.0b3

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

Change-Id: I5fea16a84c881d0e66b713cdb55c8dcabcb80491

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I1a4e7050ae4d21af90362f80694e719338b2a5b3

properly escape the release notes text

Escape the list entries as blocks of text so the YAML parser
understands how to process them.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
use . instead of source.

Code conventions: Use “.” to source script files
When you have to source a script file, for example ,
a credentials file to gain access to user-only or
 admin-only CLI commands, use . instead of source.
See more:
http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/writing-style/code-conventions

Change-Id: Ic4fd2da622f21e51f813e711cdedb7d1998592fd

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I34e200375e555d5ba86a9f6a6209132ddd2485a6

[{'created': '2018-01-25 18:24:35.000000000', 'message': "Remove infracloud-chocolate from nodepool

Because we've lost access to infracloud-chocolate controller, we
cannot properly remove it from nodepool.  As such, remove
configuration from nodepool and grafana.

It was a fun run while it lasted!

Change-Id: I589732d76761275b88dd153ff9e55a78d35483eb
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Remove infracloud-chocolate from nodepool

Because we've lost access to infracloud-chocolate controller, we
cannot properly remove it from nodepool.  As such, remove
configuration from nodepool and grafana.

It was a fun run while it lasted!

Change-Id: I589732d76761275b88dd153ff9e55a78d35483eb
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
python-blazarclient 1.0.1

This should correct the broken 1.0.0 release. The diff-start instruction
applies to the release announcement email to ensure all of the 1.0.0
changes are included there.

Change-Id: Idf2329fa0766ae99426649fd33a21870ccddf95b
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 for project retirement
messages:
[{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-29 00:58:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-29 15:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There are still a few projects using django-openstack-auth. What sort of impact will this release have on those projects?

  castellan-ui          requirements.txt           django_openstack_auth>=3.5.0  # Apache-2.0
  cue-dashboard         requirements.txt           django-openstack-auth>=2.0.0 # Apache-2.0
  meteos-ui             requirements.txt           django-openstack-auth>=2.2.0 # Apache-2.0'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-29 15:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> There are still a few projects using django-openstack-auth. What sort of impact will this release have on those projects?
> 
>   castellan-ui          requirements.txt           django_openstack_auth>=3.5.0  # Apache-2.0
>   cue-dashboard         requirements.txt           django-openstack-auth>=2.0.0 # Apache-2.0
>   meteos-ui             requirements.txt           django-openstack-auth>=2.2.0 # Apache-2.0

These projects actually does not use openstack_auth (which is a python module provided by django-openstack-auth) directly.
In queens cycle, horizon imports django-openstack-auth code and "openstack_auth" python module is provided by "horizon" now,
so "openstack_auth" is still provided. If horizon queens depends on django-openstack-auth transition package, they should work as-is.
(Note that these projects does not need to depend on django-openstack-auth directly.)

In addition, meteos-ui and cue-dashboard has no commit during Queens cycle.
castellian-ui has two commits around the infra change in Queens and there is no release so far.
I am not sure how we need to care them.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-29 16:04:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > There are still a few projects using django-openstack-auth. What
 > sort of impact will this release have on those projects?
 > >
 > >   castellan-ui          requirements.txt

 > >   cue-dashboard         requirements.txt          
 > django-openstack-auth>=2.0.0 # Apache-2.0
 > >   meteos-ui             requirements.txt          
 > django-openstack-auth>=2.2.0 # Apache-2.0
 > 
 > These projects actually does not use openstack_auth (which is a
 > python module provided by django-openstack-auth) directly.

OK, good.

 > In queens cycle, horizon imports django-openstack-auth code and
 > "openstack_auth" python module is provided by "horizon" now,
 > so "openstack_auth" is still provided. If horizon queens depends on
 > django-openstack-auth transition package, they should work as-is.
 > (Note that these projects does not need to depend on
 > django-openstack-auth directly.)
 > 
 > In addition, meteos-ui and cue-dashboard has no commit during
 > Queens cycle.
 > castellian-ui has two commits around the infra change in Queens and
 > there is no release so far.
 > I am not sure how we need to care them.

Thank you for doing that analysis. I think it's safe to do this release.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-29 16:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-01-29 16:27:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-29 16:38:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Please see my reply on the mailing list. I think we're going about this a little backwards."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-29 17:18:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Under discussion on #openstack-releases IRC channel.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-01-29 17:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

In the discussion on IRC, we agreed there is no need for the new release of d-o-a. The horizon team will update the release note more clearly to ensure to uninstall django-openstack-auth when upgrading horizon to queens.

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-release/%23openstack-release.2018-01-29.log.html#t2018-01-29T16:02:35'}]

[{'created': '2018-01-29 00:58:10.000000000', 'message': 'Release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 for project retirement

It was suggested to create a new major version of django-openstack-auth
as a transitional package to stop providing any module itself.
Queens release of horizon is planned to depend on the new DOA release.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126431.html

While django-openstack-auth queens deliverable file was removed
in commit 61d637ad16, considering the above suggestion, it sounds better
to release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 as queens deliverable.

Note that stable/queens branch is not needed due to the project retirement.

Change-Id: Ib0679150a8d70c328496c7104636983641b8c3e0
'}]
commit_message:
Release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 for project retirement

It was suggested to create a new major version of django-openstack-auth
as a transitional package to stop providing any module itself.
Queens release of horizon is planned to depend on the new DOA release.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126431.html

While django-openstack-auth queens deliverable file was removed
in commit 61d637ad16, considering the above suggestion, it sounds better
to release django-openstack-auth 4.0.0 as queens deliverable.

Note that stable/queens branch is not needed due to the project retirement.

Change-Id: Ib0679150a8d70c328496c7104636983641b8c3e0

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I49df89c5fcd7f119cdbd0ffd977ca124a2e51cda

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 15:52:46.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Add regression test wrinkle for rebuilding twice with invalid image

This shows that if we fail to rebuild with an invalid image, we are
able to rebuild a second time with the same image and it's allowed.
This is due to a bug where the API saves the new image ref on the
instance and doesn't roll it back when the scheduling failure occurs,
so that the subsequent attempt with the invalid image is allowed because
the API sees that the image isn't changing (even though the backing
image on the instance never changed) and the scheduler is bypassed.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1539703

Change-Id: Ibc4a2a3c885c23c74edfd6435076675317068868
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Add regression test wrinkle for rebuilding twice with invalid image

This shows that if we fail to rebuild with an invalid image, we are
able to rebuild a second time with the same image and it's allowed.
This is due to a bug where the API saves the new image ref on the
instance and doesn't roll it back when the scheduling failure occurs,
so that the subsequent attempt with the invalid image is allowed because
the API sees that the image isn't changing (even though the backing
image on the instance never changed) and the scheduler is bypassed.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1539703

Change-Id: Ibc4a2a3c885c23c74edfd6435076675317068868

some part needs to be fixed (This is WIP patch so ignore if you're fixing this other way)"}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:33:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:39:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@spyros and @rico, need your comments here. Do we need to expose the affinity policy as a parameter for cluster or we just want to hardcode it as 'soft-anti-affinity' at this moment? Thanks.

If we don't want to hardcode this policy, then we may have to add a new attribute for clsuter's data model and need a db schema change, which I'm not sure if it's always a preferred way in Magnum."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2017-12-19 09:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Support soft-anti-affinity policy for nodes

Currently, there is no guarantee to make sure all nodes of one cluster are
created on different compute hosts. So it would be nice if we can create
a server group and set it with anti-affinity policy to get a better HA
for cluster. This patch is proposing to create a server group for master
and minion nodes with soft-anti-affinity policy by default.

Closes-Bug: #1737802

Change-Id: Icc7a73ef55296a58bf00719ca4d1cdcc304fab86

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Iac1150ec8dc2529339bc65e552b5ef15b92c438d

commit_message:
Adds Workflow to List Available Roles

This patch adds a workflow to list available roles for a given
deployment plan by reading the roles directory in the plan's
swift container and returning a json structure of role yaml
files present.

Implements: blueprint tripleo-common-list-available-roles-action

Change-Id: I23087bd38c3730c9f24e03e4d7c54688ae912b08

commit_message:
Ensure to mark exception message as tranlation strings

- in exception.py Class ServiceCatalogException
  an exception message is untranslated,
- in k2k.oy Class K2KAuthPlugin def get_plugin
  an exception message is untranslated.

Change-Id: I7d09f625cc3e074bc5a40478668c7b382613da2f
Signed-off-by: peiy <peiy@rc.inesa.com>

commit_message:
Load undercloud DB password to a mistral environment

This patch adds a new variable to the mistral
environment 'tripleo.undercloud-config' allowing
to retrieve the root password for the MySQL
databases. Now this variable can be accessed from any
Mistral workflow.
Also, this patch adds the ability of checking if
the variables are not loaded properly due to
an upgrade, in that case we update the Mistral
environment to have all the variables in place.

Change-Id: I822c3d96b5805909656d8e92e963b851f3bd77de
(cherry picked from commit be3bd48214e6719db9bd364f020ea5b652b9a536)
Related-Bug: 1742191

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I7dfd1866dc812d00d5cfefad883c12fe843199a0

commit_message:
use openstack command instead of nova command

In function 'get_instance_ip', 'nova' client command is used to get
instance information in order to retrive IP address of the instance.

There is no need to use the nova command, since 'openstack' client
already supports such basic operation.

Moreover, 'openstack' client has an option to get value of specified
column. That brings more accurate way of retriving IP address.

This patch replaces nova command in 'get_instance_ip' by 'openstack'
command. Note, this nova command is the only one in devstack tree.

Change-Id: Iee0b81a994a4da5b3f4572c2e8eb30514cd43f89
Signed-off-by: Ryota MIBU <r-mibu@cq.jp.nec.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-22 10:40:12.000000000', 'message': 'Future of classic drivers: update the migration proposal

As I started working on the migration implementation, it became
apparent that the current proposal is not the best. This patch
makes the following changes:

1. Do not calculate migration per node, but rather per driver. Doing
   it per node is not required for the current classic drivers.
   It complicates the database code and makes it potentially less
   efficient, because we need to fetch and update every node
   separately.

2. Return hardware type and interfaces separately from to_hardware_types.
   Also return interfaces without _interface suffix. This simplifies
   additional checks in the migration code.

3. Add support for options in migrations, and add an option to reset
   unsupported interfaces to no-<interface>. This is needed to make
   this migration more usable. For example, for ``pxe_ipmitool``
   to be migrated under the current proposal, a deployment must have
   ``agent`` RAID and ``shellinabox`` console enabled, even if it
   does not use and/or does not support them. The new options will
   allow such deployments to have unsupported interfaces reset.

Change-Id: I194be98bdd1f307ce6b9054a0037788f81cb0d23
Related-Bug: #1690185
'}]
commit_message:
Future of classic drivers: update the migration proposal

As I started working on the migration implementation, it became
apparent that the current proposal is not the best. This patch
makes the following changes:

1. Do not calculate migration per node, but rather per driver. Doing
   it per node is not required for the current classic drivers.
   It complicates the database code and makes it potentially less
   efficient, because we need to fetch and update every node
   separately.

2. Return hardware type and interfaces separately from to_hardware_types.
   Also return interfaces without _interface suffix. This simplifies
   additional checks in the migration code.

3. Add support for options in migrations, and add an option to reset
   unsupported interfaces to no-<interface>. This is needed to make
   this migration more usable. For example, for ``pxe_ipmitool``
   to be migrated under the current proposal, a deployment must have
   ``agent`` RAID and ``shellinabox`` console enabled, even if it
   does not use and/or does not support them. The new options will
   allow such deployments to have unsupported interfaces reset.

Change-Id: I194be98bdd1f307ce6b9054a0037788f81cb0d23
Related-Bug: #1690185

commit_message:
Running new workflow based on an existing execution.

This change would allow an operator to start a new workflow execution
based on an existing one, it would also recall all parameters needed
to start the workflow.

Implements blueprint: mistral-run-workflow-from-execution
Change-Id: Iec3d9f3a71a98952860b972acd09ce80e0a849ff

commit_message:
Add support for synchronous commit

This patch changes the default driver behavior to synchronously
commit messages following consumer poll. A configuration option
will enable the auto commit for asynchronous commit if desired.

Depends-On: I5b4f01c928373cac530aa6877a34c684577bc64e
Change-Id: I92a3dc95c5d424aa722138195fef5a855a66b31d

commit_message:
Base mechanism for recovery

This patch introduces default implmentation of get_resource method
to ResourceBaseDriver class to allow recovery mechanism to fetch a
resource based on id. If a driver wants to provide its own
implementation then introduced method has to be overridden.

Change-Id: I951d05783ccbe1bc873a76511d254f90e71a4914
Partial-Bug: #1713697

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: Ic5b3aa676faef630130f1c75fbb45f5f6d10ffe0

subject: Fix unit tests for ML2 Mechanism driver
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 333, 'name': 'Isaku Yamahata', 'email': 'isaku.yamahata@gmail.com', 'username': 'yamahata'}, {'_account_id': 6854, 'name': 'YAMAMOTO Takashi', 'email': 'yamamoto@midokura.com', 'username': 'yamamoto'}, {'_account_id': 7921, 'name': 'Mike Kolesnik', 'email': 'mkolesni@redhat.com', 'username': 'mkolesni'}, {'_account_id': 13912, 'name': 'rajiv', 'email': 'thenakliman@gmail.com', 'username': 'rajiv.kumar'}, {'_account_id': 17120, 'name': 'Manjeet Singh Bhatia', 'email': 'manjeet.s.bhatia@intel.com', 'username': 'manjeets'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26507, 'name': 'Michel Peterson', 'email': 'michel@redhat.com', 'username': 'mpeterson'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:12:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

IMPORTANT: Until this patch is merged no other patches should be merged.

I think we only need to add the test for the mechanism test cases. However, please think thoroughly if it needs to be added to other TestCases where _mechanism_driver is provided.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:24:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-29 18:03:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

There are 7 tests that fail now that we are actually testing the driver.

Again, I ask you to kindly review if there are other test cases where we depend on the mechanism driver to be instantiated and used so we can add this. From a quick review it seems that's the only place that was missing it but I could be wrong and I have to head back home."}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2017-11-29 23:45:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Nice catch!
test_mechanism_odl.py has similar issue too?  But it's planned to be removed soon, so it's doubtful to fix it.


Your request for review is, is it okay to move pluinsetup to _OpenDaylightMechanismBase instead of base_v2.OpenDaylightTestCase?


- dhcp testcases, OdlDhcpDriverTestBase, needs odl plugin because it uses core plugin.

- OpenDaylightJournalThreadTest and JournalTest don't need to inherit OpenDaylightTestCase, but OpenDaylightConfigBase.

- test_trunk_driver_v2 uses core plugin, so ml2 odl driver is needed.

- test cases for l2gw, bgpvpn, lbaas, qos look okay because they don't use core plugin.

Maybe we'd like to move _OpenDaylightMechanismBase into base_v2.py?"}, {'account_id': 7921, 'date': '2017-11-30 08:31:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Nice catch!
 > test_mechanism_odl.py has similar issue too?  But it's planned to
 > be removed soon, so it's doubtful to fix it.
 > 
 > 
 > Your request for review is, is it okay to move pluinsetup to
 > _OpenDaylightMechanismBase instead of base_v2.OpenDaylightTestCase?
 > 

I believe he did it because thats what neutron ML2 plugin expects, otherwise it won't load our mechanism and extension drivers.

 > 
 > - dhcp testcases, OdlDhcpDriverTestBase, needs odl plugin because
 > it uses core plugin.
 > 
 > - OpenDaylightJournalThreadTest and JournalTest don't need to
 > inherit OpenDaylightTestCase, but OpenDaylightConfigBase.

This is unrelated to the change though..

 > 
 > - test_trunk_driver_v2 uses core plugin, so ml2 odl driver is
 > needed.
 > 
 > - test cases for l2gw, bgpvpn, lbaas, qos look okay because they
 > don't use core plugin.
 > 
 > Maybe we'd like to move _OpenDaylightMechanismBase into base_v2.py?"}, {'account_id': 7921, 'date': '2017-11-30 08:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-30 13:44:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-11-30 13:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7921, 'date': '2017-12-03 13:51:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I believe you need to add something similar to the V1 driver's code [1] for port mac update test since ODL doesn't support it based on [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/networking-odl/blob/master/networking_odl/tests/unit/ml2/test_mechanism_odl.py#L202
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L305"}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-12-04 09:57:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2017-12-12 00:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Michael, I thought you'll also address the found issues because you've clamed to block other patches until this patch(with fixes of found bugs) is merged.
Is it true or not?
I'm wondering if we should merge or hold other patches."}, {'account_id': 333, 'date': '2017-12-12 00:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

-1 for reply and fixing found bugs.'}, {'account_id': 26507, 'date': '2017-12-13 12:33:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1 Code-Review-1

Isaku, 

thanks to your comment I realized that I forgot to send an email about it.

commit_message:
Fix unit tests for ML2 Mechanism driver

The class that tests the ML2 Mechanism driver was relying on a
configuration parameter that was not honored by the `Ml2PluginV2TestCase`
class. As a result, all TestCases that relied on this mechanism were not
instantiating the `opendaylight_v2` driver.

This patch sets the correct variable to allow the parent class to
instantiate the driver. In addition, it adds a test that will allow to
make sure that if there are any changes on the parent class and the
mechanism driver is not instantiated, then it will fail the unit tests.

Change-Id: I4bf2533ba6382a61e6dc010786da1d685a509781

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-15 16:52:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix missing variables in devstack/override-defaults

The mechanism to override defaults in devstack is called very early in
the stack process, even before calling the plugin.sh of the plugin that
is being loaded. This causes an issue, since the default settings of ODL
live in devstack/settings.odl but they are not imported by the time the
override mechanism is called and therefore it doesn't execute correctly.

This patch makes sure that the override mechanism imports the default
settings of ODL before executing the script. That way we can depend on
those settings being existent and reused.

Change-Id: I1da6d6111b713c38fc4a7460fc72981faab1a10d
"}, {'created': '2018-01-23 13:05:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix missing variables in devstack/override-defaults

The mechanism to override defaults in devstack is called very early in
the stack process, even before calling the plugin.sh of the plugin that
is being loaded. This causes an issue, since the default settings of ODL
live in devstack/settings.odl but they are not imported by the time the
override mechanism is called and therefore it doesn't execute correctly.

This patch makes V2 of the driver as the default choice unless otherwise
specified.

Change-Id: I1da6d6111b713c38fc4a7460fc72981faab1a10d
"}]
commit_message:
Fix missing variables in devstack/override-defaults

The mechanism to override defaults in devstack is called very early in
the stack process, even before calling the plugin.sh of the plugin that
is being loaded. This causes an issue, since the default settings of ODL
live in devstack/settings.odl but they are not imported by the time the
override mechanism is called and therefore it doesn't execute correctly.

This patch makes V2 of the driver as the default choice unless otherwise
specified.

Change-Id: I1da6d6111b713c38fc4a7460fc72981faab1a10d

up devstack and allows to build a job on top of that. The second one
does exactly that, allowing the test to be determined by a tox
environment.

commit_message:
Add devstack base jobs specific to the project

This patch adds two jobs:
  - networking-odl-devstack-base
  - networking-odl-devstack-base-tox

They both allow to run CI jobs with devstack. The first one brings
up devstack and allows to build a job on top of that. The second one
does exactly that, allowing the test to be determined by a tox
environment.

Change-Id: I455ed925534b0adabf54dafa3ad3b607ec682956

subject: Add neutron's tempest plugin to the CI

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-25 14:06:40.000000000', 'message': "Add neutron's tempest plugin to the CI

Towards ensuring a greater coverage of scenarios during CI runs we want
to include tempest tests that are part of the [Neutron test battery].
They were [split to separate repository], so we need to include them and
trigger their run.

[Neutron test battery]:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin
[split to separate repository]:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html

Based on: I4d6f3609f528ea623d698e83be5482e5aeeb0776

Co-Authored-By: Mike Kolesnik <mkolesni@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ic4264e6d934b44ee39a450fea9525c71f35ba18f

commit_message:
Add neutron's tempest plugin to the CI

Towards ensuring a greater coverage of scenarios during CI runs we want
to include tempest tests that are part of the [Neutron test battery].
They were [split to separate repository], so we need to include them and
trigger their run.

[Neutron test battery]:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin
[split to separate repository]:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html

Based on: I4d6f3609f528ea623d698e83be5482e5aeeb0776

Co-Authored-By: Mike Kolesnik <mkolesni@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ic4264e6d934b44ee39a450fea9525c71f35ba18f

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I6db4d23c544399d258bd035a34351b34cb437409

Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

[{'created': '2018-01-28 02:20:06.000000000', 'message': "Stop using openstack server remove floating ip

The openstack server remove floating ip CLI no longer works
with python-novaclient 10.0.0 directly because novaclient
removed it's deprecated API bindings for updating a floating
IP to unset it's associated port.

We need to fix python-openstackclient, deprecate that CLI and
eventually remove it, but at the same time, we can get ahead of
that deprecation and change to the 'floating ip unset --port' CLI.

Change-Id: I63d69bc2b96df04777f00f32930e92564e33e8c2
Closes-Bug: #1745795
"}]
commit_message:
Stop using openstack server remove floating ip

The openstack server remove floating ip CLI no longer works
with python-novaclient 10.0.0 directly because novaclient
removed it's deprecated API bindings for updating a floating
IP to unset it's associated port.

We need to fix python-openstackclient, deprecate that CLI and
eventually remove it, but at the same time, we can get ahead of
that deprecation and change to the 'floating ip unset --port' CLI.

Change-Id: I63d69bc2b96df04777f00f32930e92564e33e8c2
Closes-Bug: #1745795

commit_message:
Start using ipv6 nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create ipv6 multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd.

Change-Id: Iba56667e11510a1cc2470a7dfdc6bc0158878010
(cherry picked from commit 3fc4da76ab0970b6cc2a2648d1908158fa0fcc02)

commit_message:
Start using nic-configs from THT repo instead of tripleo-ci

This patch uses the net-iso gen tool to create multi-nic network
isolation templates with the same settings we currently use in CI.
Rather than overwrite existing example configs in the network dir,
we instead create a new dir under ci/environments to hold the
nic-configs we use in CI jobs. This alleviates any concerns about
backwards-compatibility and breaking users on upgrade.

We may want to also consider a massive cleanup of the existing
network dir with a proper deprecation period, but that is an
exercise left for later.

By moving these nic-configs to THT, we are bringing them inline
with the other heat environments we have moved out of the CI repo.
It also allows an end user to start from a configuration that we
have actually CI'd (though there are some settings like MTU that
are not actually good for a real deployment).

Change-Id: I9fd8b8bbcf18d26b1e05d33e2598c0d146814aff
(cherry picked from commit 10b749c043700369d4ea89d5a238173c4dde1d7e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-24 03:48:54.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure idl.run() called on TRY_AGAIN

If the DB connection drops after Connection.run() calls idl.run()
but before Transaction.do_commit(), then it is possible for
idl.commit() to return TRY_AGAIN due to the failure of session.send().
This prevents commit_block() from running idl.run() which would
actually trigger the DB reconnect, causing each successive call to
commit_block() to fail in the same way until we stop trying again
due to timeout and Connection.run() calls idl.run() again.

For now, we can just ensure that idl.run() is called when we get a
TRY_AGAIN. It might be worth it to refactor this a bit to not even
use commit_block().

Change-Id: I77402bde3fc4d45c770b9f48882870cfc91d719d
Closes-Bug: #1741889
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure idl.run() called on TRY_AGAIN

If the DB connection drops after Connection.run() calls idl.run()
but before Transaction.do_commit(), then it is possible for
idl.commit() to return TRY_AGAIN due to the failure of session.send().
This prevents commit_block() from running idl.run() which would
actually trigger the DB reconnect, causing each successive call to
commit_block() to fail in the same way until we stop trying again
due to timeout and Connection.run() calls idl.run() again.

For now, we can just ensure that idl.run() is called when we get a
TRY_AGAIN. It might be worth it to refactor this a bit to not even
use commit_block().

Change-Id: I77402bde3fc4d45c770b9f48882870cfc91d719d
Closes-Bug: #1741889

commit_message:
Handle images with no data

There isn't really much we can do with these images, which glance tells
us are possible [1]. Simply raise an exception.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/python-glanceclient/latest/reference/api/glanceclient.v2.images.html

Change-Id: I5f81393a5bb41e6a674369afb899d8a41bb2c3b4
Closes-Bug: #1736759

commit_message:
tests: Use correct response type in tests

An instance of 'glanceclient.utils.common.RequestIdProxy' is returned
for most calls to glanceclient. Correct the unit tests to reflect this.

- https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/2.8.0/glanceclient/common/utils.py#L542
- https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/2.8.0/glanceclient/v2/images.py#L199

Change-Id: I1a0a7c80d6ca53d0ac8821b2e63dd43593e6c822

[{'created': '2018-01-25 15:46:27.000000000', 'message': "Resolve race in validating neutron networks due to caching

This patch removes the caching from the code that validates neutron
network's name and UUID to solve a race caused by storing a network UUID

object.

Change-Id: Ib5fb1ff93ffecec4b5ffb033013d3ae09dcaf4bc
"}]
commit_message:
Resolve race in validating neutron networks due to caching

This patch removes the caching from the code that validates neutron
network's name and UUID to solve a race caused by storing a network UUID
(which can now be different per node) on a singleton network interface
object.

Change-Id: Ib5fb1ff93ffecec4b5ffb033013d3ae09dcaf4bc

commit_message:
Add  liveness probe to Kuryr Controller.

This patch allows health checks of handlers and k8s API watchers.
It sends a signal to Health Manager when an exception occurred in
the watcher threads or when the retry reached the deadline for
a handler.

Change-Id: Ifa6422148fdc25aed83e7d501218d2fd57c17cfb
Related-Bug: #1705429

commit_message:
Remove commas in setup.cfg package classifiers

This is likely causing an upload to pypi to fail with the following
error:

   Error: 'Development Status :: 3 - Alpha,' is not a valid choice for this field

Change-Id: Ic7f6e082644a6c2ba8820ae6f343640bc8e430c4

commit_message:
devstack: Avoid using $NEUTRON_CORE_PLUGIN too early

After a recent change [1] our devstack plugin uses
$NEUTRON_CORE_PLUGIN too early, even before lib/neutron,
which sets the default value of the variable, is sourced.
This commit moves it to a later phase. (run_phase source)

[1] I2353bdcbe5d9b77fd1d5941bc672d5bab53717ef

Closes-Bug: #1710734
Change-Id: I1399ecf37ad47405239e86ebfe9c36a6de2807be

[{'created': '2017-12-13 18:03:52.000000000', 'message': "Modify flavors for integration tests

This patch proposes:
* Use default devstack flavors instead.
* Add bigger flavor(1G ram): `ds1G_instance_type`
* Use `ds1G_instance_type` for `scenario/test_server_signal` and
  `scenario/test_server_cfn_init.py`

Consider those tests are frequently broken in heat's gate, it
shouldn't be a weast of ram to use bigger flavor for those tests.
Closes-Bug: #1738029

Change-Id: Ib7d822afacd11833c9a8e50f38a31343920e5f82
"}, {'created': '2017-12-14 04:54:21.000000000', 'message': "Modify flavors for integration tests

This patch proposes:
* Add bigger flavor(1G ram): `large_instance_type`
* Use `large_instance_type` for `scenario/test_server_signal` and
  `scenario/test_server_cfn_init.py`

Consider those tests are frequently broken in heat's gate, it
shouldn't be a weast of ram to use bigger flavor for those tests.
Closes-Bug: #1738029

Change-Id: Ib7d822afacd11833c9a8e50f38a31343920e5f82
"}]
commit_message:
Modify flavors for integration tests

This patch proposes:
* Add bigger flavor(1G ram): `large_instance_type`
* Use `large_instance_type` for `scenario/test_server_signal` and
  `scenario/test_server_cfn_init.py`

Consider those tests are frequently broken in heat's gate, it
shouldn't be a weast of ram to use bigger flavor for those tests.
Closes-Bug: #1738029

Change-Id: Ib7d822afacd11833c9a8e50f38a31343920e5f82

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

Change-Id: I3732e1ee5aabc23c9749e65670be10de42d534b9

favor of '[filter_scheduler] enabled_filters'.

commit_message:
Add monasca-tempest-plugin

We want to share some constants between monasca-log-api and
monasca-tempest-plugin.
Monasca-tempest-plugin isn't used elsewhere.

commit_message:
Pick up general URI when constructing barbican endpoint

Seems like keystone will ask barbican for its infomation
including endpoint. So barbican should handle general endpoint
e.g., 'http://localhost:9311' or 'http://localhost/key-manager'

Change-Id: Id7230198583355a83b1ee4acef3da7cde7118794
